overview.short: Kocuria kristinae is a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, non-motile coccus that may appear in tetrads, pairs, or clusters and can be misidentified as coagulase-negative Staphylococcus.
overview.clinical_context: Typically opportunistic; reported in catheter-associated bacteremia, skin/soft tissue infections, and immunocompromised hosts.

species_markers.notes: K. kristinae may produce non-distinct to faintly pigmented colonies; pigment is not a hard discriminator.
Helpful in some workflows, but not species-defining alone.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping morphology (clusters) and catalase positivity; CoNS are common lookalikes.
Same family and similar tetrad formation; requires definitive ID.

when_to_question_identification: Coagulase positivity suggests Staphylococcus aureus, not Kocuria.
Strong, consistent beta haemolysis argues against K. kristinae.
Clinically significant sterile-site isolate should be confirmed by MALDI-TOF or sequencing.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Excludes S. aureus in cluster-forming Gram-positive cocci.
Best routine method for Kocuria species identification.
Confirmatory method when species-level certainty is needed.
